title-group.article-title: An Analysis of Characteristics of Mutual Fund Mergers and Takeovers in India

abstract.p: The study examines the effect of mergers and takeovers of 55 acquiring schemes on their performance, asset growth, expense ratio, portfolio turnover and asset size using Paired t-test and Wilcoxon test. The findings show that schemes involved in "within family" mergers experience a growth in assets but a decline in expense ratio. Whereas schemes involved in "across family" mergers saw a decline in rate of growth of assets but an increase in expense ratio in the post-merger period. It appears that the main intention behind "within family" mergers is to retain assets and eliminate poor performing schemes. A multiple regression is conducted to test factors that influence post merger performance and asset growth of acquiring schemes. Results suggest that none of the factors show any significant influence on post-merger performance and asset growth of acquiring schemes. The study concludes that merger gains are more dependent on merger timings rather than any other factor.
